section.title: Required software
section.para: Download and install the software of the below list according the instructions to your operational system.

note.title: IDE tips
note.para: The project build process is based on Maven 2, but you can adopt an IDE to facilitate your work. If you adopt Eclipse , for example, you can also install its Maven plugin, that will provide you a more safe development environment. For Netbeans or Idea users, maven is integrated by default.

section.title: Environment variables
section.para:
An important detail on your environment setup is about the environment variables. Below you find an example of environment variables configuration.
export AS_HOME=/home/$USER/dev/glassfish export JAVAEE_HOME=$AS_HOME export DERBY_HOME=$AS_HOME/javadb export PATH=$PATH:$AS_HOME/bin:$DERBY_HOME/bin:$JAVA_HOME/bin:$JRUBY_HOME/bin:$GRAILS_HOME/bin export JAVA_HOME=/usr/lib/jvm/java-6-sun-1.6.0.10 export FLEX_HOME=/home/$USER/dev/flex/sdks/3.0.0 export DBF_HOME=/home/$USER/dev/DocBook-Framework-1.0 export CLASSPATH=.:$JAVA_HOME/jre/lib

section.title: Shell scripts for Linux users
section.para: The project configuration requires some repetitive tasks like to startup the Java EE container and to startup the database on every development session. In order to reduce the time consuming of these repetitive tasks, you can automatize them through Shell Scripts . In this section you find a set of scripts to run in your Linux based operational system. These scripts were tested on Ubuntu and it should work on every Linux distribution compatible with Ubuntu 8.10 or higher.

Use these commands to install it:
sudo cp glassfish /etc/init.d/ sudo chown root:root /etc/init.d/glassfish sudo chmod 755 /etc/init.d/glassfish sudo update-rc.d glassfish defaults 99
After that, you don't need to be logged in in order to have it running. But remember, booting will take longer from now on. But it's in the background, you can log in while it's starting up.
